newsitem.title: USA: Informix shares rise on Intel pact.
newsitem.headline: Informix shares rise on Intel pact.

text.p: Informix Corp shares rose as much as 13 percent after the database software company said Monday it will work with Intel Corp to develop software to better handle multimedia.

Shares of Informix, based in Menlo Park, Calif., were up 1-3/16 at 10-3/16 on Nasdaq trading of 4.38 million shares, making the stock among the most active. Earlier, the shares traded as high as 10-3/8.
Informix writes database software, the computer programs that store and retrieve huge amounts of business information on corporate computer networks.
The company in the past year concentrated on a specialized database, called Universal Server, that can handle sound and video as well as text and numbers.
The pact with Intel "is seen as an endorsement of Universal Server," said Andrew Roskill, a software analyst at investment bank Smith Barney in New York.
Informix and Intel said they will work together to optimize software and hardware to handle multimedia.

The first product from Informix will be a software add-on, called a datablade, that will help programmers take advantage of the multimedia capabilities of Intel's Pentium microprocessors, the companies said.

Earlier this year, Informix got in financial trouble by concentrating its marketing and development resources too heavily on Universal Server. Although analysts have lauded the program's technology, there is not much demand yet for what it can do, Informix executives have said.
In the first quarter, Informix reported a $140.1 million loss as revenue plunged 34 percent to $133.7 million.
